author: chris2_2_2
content: This assumes that there is no staking power rental service. With MEV its possible people will pay more than validator rewards.

author: butta
content: How does a staking power rental service look like? The renter could just get you slashed or even worse get you slashed and pocket the slashing rewards on his own validator

author: ajsutton
content: And there's no way to confirm the validator keys were given back so they could do that at any point in the future and you wouldn't know which of the renters did it.

author: potuz
content: I think it can be doable assuming trust from the renter: the validator just signs whatever the renter sends him, checking first that it's not slashable. After a couple of tries, pools with gained reputation should come up.

author: jgm
content: That's just a continual recalculation of "income from cheating" vs. "potential future income when cheating given increased reputation" i.e. a rug pull in waiting.

author: potuz
content: Well, there are a bunch of proposals for block producers in a weakly trustless manner that are more involved, this seems like a problem that will eventually be resolved.

author: out.eth
content: For the ETH2->ETH1 withdrawal - It says here that the only guarantee is that it will be a regular transfer to the ETH1 address: https://github.com/ethereum/eth2.0-specs/pull/2149. Does that mean that the user who is consuming the withdrawal receipt can specify the gas limit too?

author: djrtwo
content: Yes. and if the withdrawal TX ran out of gas and the ETH didn't make it to the destination, it would `REVERT`  and the receipt would not have been consumed so you could retry

author: out.eth
content: ok cool just confirming that the network isn't enforcing a gas limit on that tx. That gives us a lot of flexibility
